byline.contributor: James Kanter reported from Brussels and Landon Thomas Jr. from New York. Niki Kitsantonis contributed reporting from Athens.
byline.original: By JAMES KANTER and LANDON THOMAS Jr

abstract: Talks between Greece and its creditors break down, increasing likelihood that nation will be forced to default on debt of 1.6 billion euros, or $1.8 billion, owed to International Monetary Fund at end of June; Greek negotiators complain that none of European officials in talks had authority to make deal.
lead_paragraph: The lack of progress increases the possibility that Greece will be forced to default on its mountain of debt, with 1.6 billion euros owed to the International Monetary Fund on June 30.

headline.main: Fears of Greek Default Rise as Weekend Talks on Debt Payment Break Down
headline.print_headline: Debt Talks for Greece Falter Again

snippet: The lack of progress increases the possibility that Greece will be forced to default on its mountain of debt, with 1.6 billion euros owed to the International Monetary Fund on June 30.
